intro: Scilla siberica subsp. siberica, commonly known as Siberian squill, is a bulbous perennial plant native to Central Asia and parts of Eastern Europe. It typically grows to a height of 15–30 cm, featuring narrow, grass-like leaves and clusters of blue to violet, bell-shaped flowers. The plant thrives in well-drained, sandy or loamy soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Its bulbs are perennial, and it is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens. The species is also valued for its ability to naturalize and form dense colonies in suitable conditions.
